remixed_from.title: Backpacking Trekking Pole Tripod Camera Mount

description.text: Remix on Noldona's 'Backpacking Trekking Pole Tripod Camera Mount'. No more need for an adapter to connect the print to your GoPro: just screw the GoPro directly into this part!

It's a toy tiger. Printed on a makerbot replicator.
I started with the grande yellow cat source, but ReplicatorG couldn't render it to gcode and print, so I used rhino to clean up the model and remove the grass base that's on the model but not in the original picture.
Tail is still too thin to print properly. Printed with 50% infill with raft and full support.

author: KDNITRO

description.text:
This is a spring loaded scribe for the MakerFarm Prusa I3 x-carriage. I use this to remove the etch resist when fabricating printed circuit boards.

The body of the scribe is printed. A 1/4" diameter grade 8 bolt is used to make the scribe, and 1/4" T-nut and spring are used to hold the bolt in place. Both are housed in the upper portion of the body. A single machine screw holds the scribe in place on the x-carriage.

Fans Bowden V1, Anet A8, modified to ventilate the extruder and provide flow to the layer fan, eliminates vibrations derived from the fans since they are no longer clamped in the extrusion zone. We also have the advantage of preserving the direct extrusion in order to be able to print materials that can not be easily printed in a bowden system like filaflex.

Touching the tip of the nozzle with the fans on without the printer doing anything else we realize the vibrations that these fans produce. I have verified that this system does not produce vibrations derived from the fans.

Additional material required: M3 screws of various sizes, and 2 screws and several M4 threads of 50 mm. Silicone tube of 15 mm diameter on the outside of the tube and 12 mm on the inside, I have used aquarium tube, 2 blow fan 50x50x15mm 12V.

video: https://youtu.be/a6lP3ueRWzg

Ventiladores Bowden V1, Anet A8, modificación para ventilar el extrusor y aportar flujo al ventilador de capa, elimina las vibraciones derivadas de los ventiladores ya que estos ya no están sujetos en la zona de extrusión. además tenemos la ventaja de conservar la extrusión directa para poder imprimir materiales que no se pueden imprimir fácilmente en un sistema bowden como filaflex.

Tocando la punta del nozzle con los ventiladores activados sin que la impresora haga nada más nos damos cuenta de las vibraciones que dichos ventiladores producen. He comprobado que con este sistema no se producen vibraciones derivadas de los ventiladores.

Material adicional necesario: tornillos M3 de dimensiones variadas, y 2 tornillos y varias roscas M4 de 50 mm. tubo de silicona de 15 mm de diámetro en el exterior del tubo y 12 mm en el interior, yo he usado tubo de acuario, 2 ventiladores sopladores de 50x50x15 mm.
video: https://youtu.be/a6lP3ueRWzg

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,2

comments.text: Just buy Quality Fans once, they last longer and are nearly Vibration free
comments.author: Bluthunger

comments.text: Surely, but I like to think new things, so we release weight to the extruder area and we can increase the jerk, not to mention that it could adapt to closed printers so they would bring fresh air out of the box. Thanks for comment!
comments.author: Bluthunger

comments.text: Great idea... But I'd mount the fans to the base or top on an antivibration mount rather than a moving part.  Superb upgrade concept though.
comments.author: rogerlucas

comments.text: I mounted them on the Z axis because it seemed to me the place where the hoses offered less resistance but seeing the comments to the best in the next update I place them in another place. Thanks and regards!!
comments.author: rogerlucas

comments.text: Firstly... why on earth would you go to all this effort to move the fans but then just still place the fans on the x carriage? adding all that weight to the x carriage in general still? secondly... the tube doesn't need to be anywhere near that thick or heavy duty, check the maximum air speeds through smaller tubes used for fish tank aerators. Your on the right path... keep working on it man.
comments.author: MakeTheFuture

comments.text: Hi MakeTheFuture, in my opinion, the extra weight of the fans, does not affect the X axis at all, in any case would affect the Z axis which is the one that has to lift the fans, the fans do not weigh much, and I think it is not Problem for the 2 engines of Z that are also less critical in terms of movement than X and Y since these move faster and with accelerations and decelerations thing that does not happen with Z, I put them there because so the horizontal distance between the fans And the area of ​​the extruder is always the same and the hoses always make the same path in horizontal in addition to exerting the minimum resistance, the only fear I had is that the vibrations of the fans propagate along the axis reaching the area of ​​the extruder and Until the nozzle, but I have verified that it does not happen, if we put the printer without doing anything and only with the fans turned on we put the finger in the tip of the nozzle we will see that no vibration is transmitted. Anyway I am open to suggestions as to placement of the fans and I would like to know where you would put them, whatever it is to improve the invention will be welcome. Thank you very much for your comment and regards.
comments.author: MakeTheFuture

comments.text:
I think it also eliminates the extra weight of the fans on the extruder, so you are able to use high jerks.
I think when have time, will try them. Looks great!
Parecen que esta buenismo, porque le sacas peso al extrusor y eso deberìa permitir subir el jerk, pero las mangeras deberìan ser lo suficientemente blandas para no hagan fuerza sobre el extrusor, no ?
comments.author: lagabmx

comments.text: Hi, the hoses hardly resist because it absorbs the curvature of it, to me it works well, anyway this is the first version and of course there are things to improve, for example the parts that make of coupling between the hoses To the fans I want to make a looser aversion for the air to go more fluid, and the part that is coupled between the hose and the extruder, I will try to enter directly from above, or at least without so much curvature. Greetings and thanks for your comment.
comments.author: lagabmx

comments.text: Thank you, I really think it is a innovative option!

author: Tareko

title: RPi Overclocker Super Station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the stackable RPi Overclocker Super Station!

**This thing is finally finished and all files are printable! Any files downloaded before 6/4/2017 should be deleted and updated with the current files.

***On 6/6/2017, TFT Protection has been added for a protective case for the TFT when not in use. The pictures show the assembly order. For the electrical on the case fans, the Pi 3 has the 40 pin GPIO header. I use a 2 pin Dupont plug to connect to pins 4 and 6 on the Pi. From there, I split it to a 4 pin Dupont header and plug the fans in at the 4 pin header, this way, I can exchange fans without having to rewire anything and I can redesign a larger fan shroud if necessary. The splitter is then covered in heat shrink and zip tied in a way to bend the wiring to fit within the case. It works well and makes it easy to store the fan shroud when not in use.

description.text:
Remix of bookmake's End of filament sensor (switch)
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1134134

I found the mount to be very well designed. However, while it works great with most setups, it would not work so great for my setup that has bowden tubes from filament dry box, into the case, through the extruder, and to the hot end. I also added a view window that doubles as a directional arrow.

This just needs 2 M3 nuts and 2 M3 screws and splice into a bowden tube. The rest is pretty easy to setup in the firmware. Here is a helpful guide if needed:
https://nutz95.wordpress.com/2017/03/10/filament-change-module-runout-sensor-for-reprap-3d-printers/

title: Sunglasses for Oakley Jawbone lenses - Rimless Jacket Frame remix

description.text:
A car prowler stole my Oakley Bottlecaps resulting in the motivation to mix a similar style of frame with available replacement lenses. I took the liberty to make the frame a bit narrower to fit my face. Finally! - frames that fit. Awesome.

A huge shout out to kylesoehn for his excellent original Oakley Jawbone Frame design: thing:805897 - 5 minutes in Tinkercad and I had what I wanted. You rock, dude! I've reposted the original arms with spacers here for convenience.

Additional Components needed:
Snip some wire off an old heatsink, use paper-clips, or go through your spare screw collection for budget hinge pins.
Source replacement Oakley Jawbone Lenses and you're set.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1375

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Modify build area to be 124x124x120mm if on a MP Select Mini - This is getting close to the maximum size you can fit on the build plate. Rotate print diagonally and roll until it fits. Use at least 25% support density (in Cura slicer) and hope for the best

Post Printing:

Snap or pry the spacers off the model, Sand liberally with 100grit sandpaper and round any edges you want. If printing in ABS, consider an acetone bath to harden the plastic and smooth it.

Another "made up" GI Joe building, this never existed as a toy. But if the Joes, Cobra, and Oktober Guard get a base then the Iron Grenadiers should have an outpost too. AA missile launchers, two bays for tanks to fight from, and a big cannon seemed sufficient. As usual, a full scale model intended to be printed at 25%.

Updated 10/28. Added more detail tot he model. This file is better then the one posted previously.
Printing is straightforward; the base and big cannon as printed right-side up with supports.
Missile with the missiles pointed up with supports.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these. It's actually you people who are "the real American heroes" and I'm really, really proud of you.

I created these files and they are free to download. Since I did not copy any existing IP I can set the permissions as I choose. Print them, sell them, buy them, whatever. If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission.

Happy Gaming

I've been accumulating numerous small 3D printer parts (primarily hotends, fans, and wiring) and I needed a place to keep them. So I modified the designs of arcbox7 and arcbox8: I made the box square, larger, and changed the design of the top so when printed without supports the inside of the top ends up looking nice.

Doing this was pretty easy since I use parametric design software (http://birkbinnard.com/blog/parametric-modeling/), but it did take a while to get the geometry of the top's handle just right. The top fits snugly (is this like bigly?) on the bottom and is tall enough to accommodate over-filling the bottom. I used transparent yellow for this print because I thought it might be interesting to be able to see the internal structure.

The box printed in a little less than 22 1/2 hours, and the top in about 7 hours, using layer height = 0.200 mm. The box has a rippled bottom surface to prevent warping and to enable easy removal from the print bed.

Actually the OpenSCAD file is nicer because it lets you customize the through-hole wall thickness; you probably want it around 2x your nozzle width.

author: kmcclain

title: Face - proof of concept
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Want to sculpt a face? It's a concept of proof. Using OpenSCAD to sculpt a face is possible :p

Printer:

mElephant

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer

Infill:

15%

Imagine you are scanning a face, you'll get a curve for each cross section. I just perform oppositely. For simplicity, each cross section is defined by three cubic Bézier curves in my code. Because a face is symmetric, I can use only five control points to define each cross section. For example:

face_section([
    [5, 35, 7],
    [7, 35, 0],
    [17, 34, -8.5],
    [27, 34, 8.5],
    [53, 37, -20]
])

The function below calculates these points into 12 control points for three cubic Bézier curves.

function face_section(ctrl_points) = 
    let(
        middle = [
            [-ctrl_points[1][0], ctrl_points[1][1], ctrl_points[1][2]],
            [-ctrl_points[0][0], ctrl_points[0][1], ctrl_points[0][2]],
            ctrl_points[0],
            ctrl_points[1]
        ],
        right = [
            ctrl_points[1],
            ctrl_points[2],
            ctrl_points[3],
            ctrl_points[4]
        ],
        left = [
            for(i = [0:3]) 
                [
                    -right[3 - i][0],
                    right[3 - i][1],
                    right[3 - i][2]
                ]
        ]
    ) __reverse(
        concat(
            bezier_curve(resolution, left), 
            bezier_curve(resolution, middle), 
            bezier_curve(resolution, right)
        )
    );

After getting a list of cross sections for a face, I can use my polysections module to create a face:

polysections(sections);

Or use my function_grapher to get the mesh of the face.

function_grapher(
    sections, 
    thickness, 
    style = "LINES", 
    $fn = 4
);

The code below creates the mask:

difference() {
    function_grapher(
        sections, 
        thickness, 
        style = "HULL_FACES", 
        $fn = 4
    );

    translate([27, 42, 0]) 
        linear_extrude(100, center = true) 
            polygon(shape_ellipse([14, 5], $fn = 8));

    translate([-27, 42, 0]) 
        linear_extrude(100, center = true) 
            polygon(shape_ellipse([14, 5], $fn = 8));            
}

The shape_ellipse function is also included in my library.

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

author: mccand

title: Feed our Dog! - the friendly feeding reminder

description.text: This is a small item to help you remember whether your dog has eaten its meals for the day. It's made up of slider switches in two rows of 7; one switch for each of two meals a day, and a pair of switches for each day of the week. Simply slide the appropriate switch over whenever you feed your dog, and you'll know they were fed when you forget in five minutes. This item has been a big help to a forgetful me, and our dog no longer is over- (or under-) eating.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Things you'll need

14x SPDT sliding switches:
http://amzn.to/2s56Rvn

28x #4 3/8" screws:
http://amzn.to/2rdlS04

3+x ultra-fine point Sharpies
http://amzn.to/2rdCR2c

(optional) paint and a paintbrush
Any color is fine here, but lighter ones will be more visible for our purposes.

Step 1: switching things up

Using the screws, secure all 14 switches into their bays. You'll want these screws tight enough that your switches won't fall out, but not so tight that you strip the plastic out; if the plastic holes are stripped, you'll have to re-print the entire part.

Step 2: Doodling

Using your favorite Sharpie colors, shade in any parts of the print that you think need some pizzazz. I colored in the "Feed Our Dog!" logo purple, and used red and green for the two dots above each switch row; green for fed, red for not. If you're feeling ambitious (which I was not) and have a printer with multiple extruders (which I do not), you could also print these colors in plastic for a much cleaner look.

Step 3: Painting

The switches themselves are a little tricky to see, especially in dim light, so I used a drop of white paint to make each switch more visible.

This project really isn't complete yet, and here are a few things I might do in the future:

  • Add labels for the weekday the switches represent
    - Make a "Feed Our Cat!" reminder (yes, cats are also a thing)
    - Close the bottom of the reminder, though I kind of like how it's currently open

I'm open to other suggestions, which you can leave in the comments!

This case is for a quad IR receiver module that I put together on a 5cm x 7cm matrix style prototyping PCB. for info on the quad IR receiver module, see my blog: http://teslaandi.wordpress.com/2014/01/26/quad-ir-receiver-module/ The circuit uses an AND gate to combine the outputs of four IR receiver modules, giving full 360 degree coverage for robotics / AV control / laser tag systems. The inspiration for this was to simplify the tagger design for my robot, especially since it seems to be tricky to implement multiple listening IR receivers on a single arduino board.

Put together the circuit described in the attached schematic/PCB. Install in the case, using at least two of the smaller screw holes to hold the two halves together (any two will do, as the case is designed to get a snug hold on a 1.125mm thick, 5cmx7cm PCB). note: check the dimensions of your board before printing, as I made some small adjustments to the dimensions to suit my particular prototype board. For further info, see: http://teslaandi.wordpress.com/2014/01/26/quad-ir-receiver-module/

description.text: vissé a l'extrudeur pour guider le fils

Heart Design # 14

Search "wslab" over 300 designs.

The original filament monitor was giving me constant false warnings, ruining many more prints than it saved. I thought it was interference between wires, but noticed that it happened when the filament was pulled to the side and could pull away from the switch just enough to trigger it.

I made this new version from scratch to address that issue by extending the end a bit to keep it straight for the switch. I also added a slight bevel to keep it from hanging up as much.

There are some files out there for a 3DP-11, but the mounting holes were too large for my printer.

description.text: this is a Marshall amp knob copy. so if you lost original you can print reasonably looking replacement. I did add support for central hole to make it possible to print without generating supports. after print is finished you can easily remove it with knife or screw driver.

This is a remix of the excellent 3D Printable Jet Engine by CATIAV5FTW.
I modified various parts to incorporate an electric motor, to animate this wonderful model.

Print time of the set: 190 h 30 minutes.

Stay tuned with the details evolution by checking the Watch box.

06/07/2017
Optimization of "Coupleur_Moteur-arbre basse pression_V3".
This set of 2 parts provides the connection between the electric motor and the low pressure shaft of the model.
It allows a slight misalignment of the electric motor
When the engine is stopped, it allows the low-pressure compressor to spin
(People are curious and will turn the turbine by hand if you have your back turned)
Without driving the geared motor, which is not necessarily reversible with a low torque.

06/09/2017
The "coupleur_moteurV3" printed with PLA does not have the desired endurance yet.
I reprinted it with the Colorfabb XT-CF20 and the result looks better.
So I will test a 3mm V4 extension, with PLA to see if things
always move in the right direction. I want to avoid the obligation to use something other than PLA for this part that gives me a hard time.
It is also necessary to use PLA of very high quality, otherwise it breaks.

06/29/2017
The model came back from the Paris Air Show. It operated autonomously (on batteries) more than 10 hours per day, for 7 days. 2 x 9V batteries ensure a minimum of 25 hours of operation at 1Hz. With all the batteries a minimum of 100 hours operating is OK.
For the show, I installed a coupler V1, the model being in showcase and the V4 couplers not having the reliability that seemed to me necessary.

07/21/2017
Addition of the wiring diagram.
Example of suitable engines:
https://www.pololu.com/product/1585/specs
https://www.pololu.com/product/1584
This one is also suitable: Pololu item #: 1583

27/10/2017
At the request of OLGA_M, I divided the stand in two parts Left and Right to print on a smaller 3D printer.
STL and STEP files provided.
Supports needed.
A recess has been made to facilitate the alignment of the parts for assembly by gluing.

A pedido de OLGA_M, dividí el soporte en dos para imprimir en una impresora 3D más pequeña.
Archivos STL y STEP proporcionados.
Apoyos necesarios.
Se ha realizado un rebaje para facilitar la alineación de las piezas para el ensamblaje mediante encolado.

20/11/2017
To answer Olga's question about the two sets of axial clearance, I added a sectional view with arrows indicating their location. The thickness of these shims depends on the accuracy of your prints and must be adjusted accordingly. In the best case, they will not be necessary

Para responder la pregunta de Olga sobre los dos juegos de juego axial, agregué una vista en sección con flechas que indicaban su ubicación. El espesor de estas calzas depende de la precisión de sus impresiones y debe ajustarse en consecuencia. En el mejor de los casos, no serán necesarios.

Las otras partes son hardware estándar. No son piezas impresas.

Simplemente usado "Coupleur_Moteur-arbre_BP_V1_Slic3r"
Esta es una pieza de "fusible" que se romperá si alguien intenta girar la turbina a mano o detiene el compresor de baja presión mientras el motor está funcionando. Proporcione una o dos piezas de repuesto para reparar en caso de exposición pública.
Por mi parte, la turbina está bajo una campana transparente cuando la expongo.

Hello Olga
Simply used "Coupleur_Moteur-arbre_BP_V1_Slic3r"
This is a "fuse" part that will break if someone tries to spin the turbine by hand or stop the low pressure compressor while the engine is running. So provide one or two spare parts to repair in case of public exposure.
For my part, the turbine is under transparent bell when I expose it.

Best regards

N'importe quel moto-réducteur dans une enveloppe de 25 x 52 mm avec un arbre de 4 mm de diamètre avec un plat à 3,5 mm peut convenir. Celui que j'ai utilisé fait 24,8 mm à l'encastrement; 52,1 mm de long et se fixe avec 2 vis M3 à 17 mm d'entraxe. Un diamètre différent nécessitera une adaptation au support moteur.
C'est un moteur 6 Volts avec une vitesse de sortie réducteur à 261 rpm. Je fais varier la tension d'utilisation de 3,3 à 5,8 Volts à l'aide d'un convertisseur DC-DC RECOM R-78AA 6.5-0.5 SMD.
Exemple de moteurs adaptés:
https://www.pololu.com/product/1585/specs
https://www.pololu.com/product/1584
Celui ci convient aussi : Pololu item #: 1583

J'ai aussi utilisé des roulements BNL en plastique moulé
soit 2 x AC6003Z-ISB/4N/D et 2 x AC6204Z-ISB/4N/D

Restez en phase avec les évolutions de détails en cochant la case Watch.

Vous l'aurez sans doute remarqué, ceci est un remix de l'oeuvre de CATIAV5FTW pour qui j'ai le plus grand respect, étant bien placé pour savoir la quantité de travail de modélisation que ça lui a coûté.
C'est pourquoi vous ne trouverez pas ici l'ensemble des fichiers STL de ce modèle, mais seulement ceux que j'ai modifiés. ll vous faut aller télécharger les fichiers de l'objet original déposés par CATIAV5FTW et surtout lire les indications qu'il a eu la gentillesse d'écrire. Notez aussi que le fichier STEP de l'assemblage complet modifié par mes soins est disponible parmi les fichiers que j'ai déposés ce qui permettra à ceux qui le souhaitent de modifier des pièces à leur tour et de générer de nouveaux fichiers STL.
Cordialement et bonnes impressions 3D

07/06/2017
Optimisation du Coupleur_Moteur-arbre basse pression_V3.
Cet ensemble de 2 pièces assure la liaison entre le moteur électrique et l'arbre Basse pression de la maquette.
Il autorise un léger désalignement du moteur électrique
moteur à l'arrêt, il permet au compresseur basse pression de tourner
(les gens sont curieux et feront tourner la turbine à la main si vous avez le dos tourné)
sans entraîner le moto-réducteur, qui n'est pas forcément réversible avec un faible couple.

09/06/2017
Le coupleur_moteurV3 imprimé en PLA n'a pas l'endurance souhaitée.
Je l'ai réimprimé avec le XT-CF20 de Colorfabb et le résultat semble meilleur.
Je vais donc tester une V4 rallongée de 3mm, en PLA pour voir si les choses
évoluent toujours dans le bon sens. Je voudrais éviter l'obligation d'utiliser autre chose que du PLA pour cette pièce qui me donne du fil à retordre.
Il faut aussi utiliser un PLA de très haute qualité, sinon ça casse.

29/06/2017
La maquette est revenue du salon du Bourget. Elle a fonctionné de manière autonome (sur piles) plus de 10 heures par jour, pendant 7 jours. 2 piles 9V assurent un fonctionnement d'au moins 25 heures à 1Hz d'où une autonomie minimum de 100 heures.
Pour le salon, j'ai installé un coupleur V1, la maquette étant en vitrine et les coupleurs V4 n'ayant pas la fiabilité qui me semblait nécessaire.

21/07/2017
Ajout du schéma de câblage.

15/10/2017
Sortie-exposition du VOlab à la fête de la science à Groslay.

27/10/2017
A la demande de OLGA_M, j'ai divisé le stand en deux pour pouvoir l'imprimer sur une imprimante 3D plus petite. Fichiers STL et STEP fournis.
Supports nécessaires. Un encastrement a été réalisé pour faciliter l'alignement des pièces pour l'assemblage par collage.

20/11/2017
Pour répondre à la question de Olga au sujet des deux cales de réglage du jeu axial, j'ai ajouté une vue en coupe avec des flèches indiquant leur emplacement. L'épaisseur de ces cales dépend de la précision de vos impressions et doivent être ajustées en conséquence. Dans le meilleur des cas, elles ne seront pas nécessaires.

28/11/2017
Bonjour Olga
La pièce repérée 1 est l'arbre de sortie du moto-réducteur de ton choix.
Les autres pièces sont de la visserie standard. Ce ne sont donc pas des pièces imprimées.
Comme ce sont des vis mécaniques, il convient de tarauder les trous qui les reçoivent.

Cordialement

15/12/2017
Bonjour Olga
Utilises simplement "Coupleur_Moteur-arbre_BP_V1_Slic3r"
C'est une pièce "fusible" qui cassera si quelqu'un tente de faire tourner la turbine à la main ou d'arrêter le compresseur basse pression alors que le moteur tourne. Donc prévoir une ou deux pièces de rechange pour pouvoir réparer en cas d'exposition en public.
Pour ma part, la turbine est sous cloche transparente quand je l'expose.

Cordialement

20/02/2018
Ajouté les fiches techniques des composants électriques utilisés et leur sources.

Bonjour,
V1 est un accouplement fusible entre le moteur et la turbine
Il autorise un léger désaxage entre l'arbre du moteur et la turbine
et protège la turbine si un 'curieux' bloque le ventilateur (fan) ou
fait tourner la turbine à la main car le moto-réducteur que j'ai utilisé
est quasi irréversible.
V2, V3 et V4 sont des tentatives de limiteurs de couple qui ne me donnent
pas encore satisfaction car ils ne sont pas endurants probablement
pour des questions de design et de matériaux.
Pour le moment j'utilise V1 et j'en ai quelques exemplaires d'avance pour
pouvoir les remplacer en cas de casse lors des expositions.
J'ai aussi un vitrine en PMMA pour protéger la turbine des 'curieux' pendant
les expositions car je n'ai pas mieux pour le moment.
Je vous engage à lire les 'Thing details' en entier

Bonnes impressions.
Rolumix

Any gearmotor in a 25x52mm envelope with a 4mm diameter shaft with a 3.5mm flat D shape may be suitable. The one I used made 24,8mm to the recess; 52.1 mm long and fastened with 2 x M3 screws at 17mm center distance. A different diameter will require adaptation to the motor support.
This is a 6 Volt motor with a gear output speed at 261 rpm. I vary the operating voltage from 3.3 to 5.8 Volts
Using a RECOM R-78AA 6.5-0.5 SMD DC-DC converter.
From my point of view a speed of 120 rpm is perfect in presentation.
Best regards

This is a remix of gtcdman27's "Rubber band gun simi auto". I took his two parts and made a piece that would fit the two halves of the barrel together. It is keyed so it is pretty hard to mess up. It should fit together. If it doesn't fit then I would recommend filing/grinding the sections that are too big. Once it fits together nicely, glue the two sides together with the glue of your choice. Then get all of the pieces where they are supposed to go and inserted the pins. You don't have to use the pins in the "Thing Files", you can use anything that you want that makes you happy.

If there is anything that you think I can improve then just then leave a comment. I will be adding individual parts for printing in the future for those people with smaller print beds.

Here are some links to some modifications made by other users. They are worth printing and trying for yourself.

Modification 1: by kb0nly
An attachment that is designed to prevent the rubber band from catching on parts.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:296769

Modification 2: by alan_one
A modification to the ratcheting wheel that holds the rubberbands. This may or may not be necessary but you can go ahead and try it.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39464

Printer:

RepRap Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Your printer should be well calibrated, since this part has a tight fit on your PS4.

I was looking for controller stand that can be mounted on my PS4 in vertical position.

Things I found were mostly controller stands that just lift your controller a little bit above the table, or can be used for display purposes. I needed something more practical, and eye-catching at the same time.

By practical I mean space saving, that is why i put my console in vertical position, so it would be nice to occupy vertical axis with controllers too, leaving plenty of room on my table.

After few iterations of modifying and printing, I came up with the design you are looking at right now, and I am really satisfied how it turned out, and you can even fit your earbuds or USB cable through the hole :)

Enjoy!

description.text:
Safety:
First off, a hydrogen generator can be very dangerous if you are not taking the proper safety considerations.The tube producing hydrogen must be kept away from flames. I always keep a five-gallon bucket with water to place the tube in (as an added safety precaution). If safety precautions are not taken properly there is a potential risk of blowing up and sending PVC shrapnel everywhere. So safety glasses are required. Hydrogen is a useful tool but is very dangerous. You have been warned.

Disclaimer:
If you make a hydrogen generator from what I provided, I take no responsibility if you hurt yourself, others, or destroy property. Make at your own risk.

I plan to use this for an experiment to either run my generator off of hydrogen or create a hybrid system to see if my generator runs longer.

YouTube: https://youtu.be/7NqaH3yWsJw

I designed a hydrogen generator that I can run on my solar panels or on my solar generator. I used stainless steel washers and each 2 in washer alternated from positive to negative. I 3D printed a bolt to hold all the washers together. The hydrogen chamber is 4 inch PVC and the safety chamber is 2 in PVC They are held together with 2 3D printed pipe holders and there is a 3D printed stand. I use potassium carbonate as my catalyst.

comments.text: Warning: You are also creating oxygen in the same chamber. So what is bubbling out is not just hydrogen but H2 + O. And the combination is super explosive and dangerous when you have it in a sealed container. You should really add a safety disclaimer. This is actually really dangerous. If a kid looses an eye from flying PVC shrapnel it will be a shame. The second water trap will only help if you know what you are doing. If it's leaking you run the risk of exploding all the way to the big chamber.

description.text:
Completely customizable gimbal / gyro toy. Loosely based on some other designs I've seen floating around. This one, however, allows you to set your own clearances for a perfect print.

Customizer note:

This design seems to timeout on Customizer pretty easily. Try turning down "# of segments", or switch to cylindrical rings instead of spherical rings. If all else fails, download OpenSCAD and be prepared for a couple minutes of rendering.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Depending on your Customizer parameters, this print requires decent overhang. If your rings stick together or fall apart, adjust "Joint Clearance" in customizer.

However, in the long run you should try to calibrate "XY Size Compensation" (or similar) in your slicer. This will make it much easier to design and print parts with tight clearances and small features.

Be a little bit careful removing the rings from the bed. You don't want the pins to snap off or come out of their holes.
Made from scratch in OpenSCAD. Inspired by a couple similar designs I've seen. I got sick of dealing with other people's guesses for clearance and decided to make a customizable version.

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3kSMkY3ByAH

Was needing a way to align two NAM5 Wifi bridge units at long range and decided a laser pointer might work. Found the video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RSiutVlL0tM and decided that was a good idea, but felt that the there were too many places that things might not be as well aligned as possible with the wood construction so I designed one for 3D printing that should provide very accurate angles to hold the laser pointer (there are still issues with laser pointers themselves not being perfectly aligned but I can't fix that.

The jig attached to the ubiquiti NSM5 (or other Ubiquity models I suspect) using an elastic band and the laser pointer attaches to the jig with a thin elastic band. Simple but precise. Tape the laser pointer button and start aligning your radios.

Printer:

HICTOP I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printed using PLA
Used TinkerCAD to design it

Skeebot is a work-in-progress humanoid robot; the goals are ..

  • inexpensive - uses readily available micro servos
  • reasonably (but not overly) expressive; ex: should be able to walk, kick, wave arm, grip things between arms .. but not intending on adding gripping rotating fancy hands onto it
  • a good fun size, but not overly large or small; should be about 10" or so high when done

See the uploaded images for the shoulder-clamp + armbox (servo box) + hand-and-clamp and prototype torso. The legs and head are coming .. my 3d printer broke down, so just need to repair a few things to test those components.

edit: Current the torso is just an empty box (to contain battery and electronics soon); as you can see in the printed photo before I blew a couple stepper drivers, the arm and shoulder are working very nicely; the arm can rotate around in the shoulder, move at the shoulder, and move at the elbow, quite nicely. The leg is more or less an arm right now, with a foot instead of a hand .. though the feet need a lot of work yet, and I need to start writing code to see about storing actions and making it walk, rather than just flailing around like a crazy person. But it does work :)

Electronics -- I use my own homegrown pcb to drive it, but any servo-driving capable electronics should do (Arduino, r-pi, whatever.) Currently the torso is just a printable box that you might be able to fit the electronics and batteries into, but currently as I design it I'm using an umbilicle of the servo wires out the back; once I have the body done and working okay I'll resize the torso to house the electronics standalone. (ie: I am worried about balance and such once the electronics are all in there, as balance impacts walking and bending and such, so will worry about it later .. famous last words :)

Servos -- I use the Emax es08maII servos -- very small, but strong and metal-gear. Analog or digital is fine. The es08maii are about $5-$7 USD or $10 CDN in common locations (such as RC hobby stores). Shop around online!

Plastic -- I'm using PLA, but ABS or others should be fine. It works fine with the PLA 'threaded' usual 3d printed look, but with ABS you can 'gloss finish' it pretty easily, too.

SCAD files --
.. will upload the OpenSCAD files and customization instructions later on, once I've retested a few builds. I'll have to work on some devo videos and tutorial videos once its done, but that's a ways off yet :)

Tools -- not much is needed, but you'll probably want a rounded file; ie: theres no way to avoid a bit of overhand on the armbox or some of the other parts, and if it droops a little.. just hit with the file to make sure the servos or axles fit in place; its designed to be a fairly tight fit for the servos, so they lock into place and make everything move nicely without any external screws on the horns, but we'll see.

In general, I use only a couple scad files, but there are variables defined at the top to tell it which parts to spit out, and which bits to include (for example, see the photos .. I can include the servos in the display to help visualize sizing, but when printing out parts you naturally remove the servos since you'll place real ones in there instead.)

TODO

  • need to round off the edges; the hand may rub on the armbox when waving around, say
  • make it adjustable for other common servos (ultra common SG90 plastic servo, etc)
  • the shoulder-mount is currently just a cutout for the servo horn cross on torso, which is fine, but the arm will fall off .. the horn cutout needs to only be half deep (say) and have some screw holes, but I want to tweak that married-connection to be stronger and simpler
  • etc etc .. lots to do :)

author: edonnelly

print_settings.Notes:: Print only one clamp, M5 or M6, depending on your available fittings

description.text:
For those 3DS Cube 3 owners: This submission is to replace the stock 3DS cartridges with a bulk filament hub for improved performance and convenience. The core option is a remote filament solution. Everything in a stock cartridge will convert to this solution.

NOTE: This "solution" provides a push-to-connect fitting with either an M5 or M6 thread to connect to a feeder tube of your making. There are 4mm tubing and hot-end solutions and some have had luck with 3mm tubing. With another adapter, even the stock tubing can be put back into service. Although that is where 90% of filament feed problems spawn from.

These are only useful for Cube 3 printers, so that is the format of the print files.

The included STL is an accessory template in case you want to make your own spool holder.

The included despoolers are for the stock 3DS spool.
Feel free to make your own accessory with the included template file in STL format.

Attaching an accessory to the clamp requires 2 each M5 cap screws (common bicycle hardware).
The screw length can be from 8-12mm long. Other mounting options can be imagined.

For more about this Thing and all things 3D Printing, visit www.print3dforum.com

Printer Brand:

3D Systems

Printer:

Cube 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200

Infill:

strong

Notes:

Optimized and fixed for your protection :)

Files support Left side PLA only on your Cube3 printer using the stock Cubify application v4.03.

Print only one clamp, M5 or M6, depending on your available fittings

This is fairly straight forwards but just in case.

Key takeaway: The filament should feed without restriction through the hub. Careful attention to the images below will help you glean the operations. Feel free for clarification in comments as needed.

Supports are built in. If it looks like it shouldn't be attached, it probably shouldn't be.

Chip holders are little springs. Do not use brittle material. They print in pairs for best results.
Some cleanup in the pocket may be required. Chips should recess slightly.

Depending on your 1st layer gap, you may need to clean up a few edges where there are holes.
The through hole for filament is 2-2.2mm, the hole at the feeder tube is 2.8-3mm.
Reaming with a hex wrench will make short work of ensuring proper clearances.

Threaded holes are ready to use; however, a poor-man's tap is recommended if the threads feel too tight.

Feeder guide M6 fitting with guide M5 fitting guide (note the 4mm tubing filler, chamfer for filament guide) Driver installed Chip installed slightly sub-flush; note the chip's orientation.

Collaborative Effort

This project had a reluctant start. I still believe in modifying stock cartridges because they are convenient for travel. The group effort from good people at the Print3DForum had nailed this effort with a very simple solution called the KISS Carts.

Another effort started to install a permanent feeder on the Cube 3. Eventually, it lead to just driving the filament with a file so now a dual effort has come to light. This is one of them.

Please do not hate me for not releasing the STL files. In order to support something this simple is to define a complex design. I am willing to support this project but I need to know what was printed before a conversation becomes meaningful. This process lets the conversation commence much sooner.

And for those who want their own, I welcome anyone to copy and change the design. If you can extract an STL from the .cube3 files, go for it. I certainly am not trying to stifle anyone else's efforts.

title: InMoov Neck Head Bracket Another Redesign

description.text:
First I want to say: THANK YOU Gael for this amazing open source robot. We could not have done this without you! And thanks to all that has taken their time to design amazing mods. This is one of mine I'm working on.

I started my InMoov robot not to long ago. I started with the head and there are SO many mods for this thing. I decided to go with a little of Gael Langevin's version mixed with Mats Önnerby version for the head and eyes. I wanted the Rpi for future uses in the head but with Gael new eye mod (inspired by Mats' design). However, I found that using Gael's eyes will interfere with the motion while using the Mats' NeckRedesignV5.stl. Basically the bracket in the front needs to be remove or moved back. But by doing this it causes the jaw servo to be moved. This lead me to redesign the whole piece and some other parts

I've wanted to design this thing so that it had could support all these features:

  • Removable RPI and Audrino through ears
  • More head space above for circulating lights like the NeoPixel Ring (printing exterior with transparent filament)
  • Speaker mount holes
  • Mats' Modified InMoov head (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992918)
  • Gael's new eye mechanism (http://inmoov.fr/eye-mechanism/)
  • Gear system so wire can be ran through neck made by Andreas Klein(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1581955).
  • Low back bracket I redesigned as well to work with Gael's new face panel mounts (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2335838)
  • Make it look like a crab claw. Kidding!

Update 5/26/2017:

  • trimmed back of face arms slightly
  • enlarged gap for eye mechanism bottom servo (to clear up/down movement)
  • added wire holes for speaker and neck brace
  • add speaker spacer to lower speaker (eye mechanism would hit it)
  • offset speaker holes to one side (made room for eye mechanism)
  • reduced holes for neck mount to make slightly tighter fit (sand if you want it more loos)
  • moved optional center servo mount back a little to clear eye mechanism; had to make new neck clamp to allow rotation of head

=======================
To sum it all up, you will need:

1.) Mats Önnerby Part 1 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992918) files:

  • JawPistonV2.stl (just the piston part not the bracket)
  • SkullTopV1.stl
  • HeadStandNeckHolder.stl (optional)

2.) Mats Önnerby Part 2 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:994720) file:

  • ArduinoUnoV2.stl

3.) Zygmunt Wojcik RPI holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:754078) file

  • raspberrry_bPlus_2b.stl

4.) Andreas Klein Neck Gear (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1581955) files:

  • NeckDriveGearV1.stl
  • NeckUpperJointV1a.stl

5.) My Low Back Skull Mod for Andreas Klein Neck Gear mod (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2335838)

  • InMoov_LowBackSkull_gear_remix.stl

6.) Gael Langevin's eye mechanism (http://inmoov.fr/wp-content/uploads/stl/Eyes-mechanism/InMoov-eyes-mechanism.zip) all files

Did I miss anything?

I will post pictures when I complete the print and get my servos.

Anet A8

No

15%

Notes:

description.text:
I am using 10 series ( 1"x1" or 2525) extruded aluminum to build a 3d printer , and I had a hard time fined the sliding nuts to fit so i made this .
Theses are designed using #10-32 nuts from home depot link is here
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-10-32-Zinc-Plated-Machine-Screw-Nut-100-Pieces-18532/202249714

I had a couple things artsy things around the house that have just been sitting around on tables collecting dust or worse and I decided to hang them up.

I designed this parametrically in Fusion 360 and i've included the Fusion 360 file here so you can make one that fits your needs.

Though it probably doesn't make much difference... since I've designed this for a round flat object, instead of a flat mating surface on the clip it actually takes into account the curvature of the plate when it draws the clip.

A remix with some small adjustments

  • Shortened the base to make it easier to print on smaller printers
  • Flattened the bulge on one side of the frame so that the piece sits flat on print bed
  • Shortened the hooks

Update: Added a wider (more open) version of the hooks. This may work better for tablets that have a case.

This is a model of Shakespears Globe Theatre in London.

The 30mm Fan on my Solidoodle Printer's hotend was not running fast enough, although oiling helped for a week or two - so I decided to add an Oil reservoir to keep it oiled for several months.

I removed the cover from the fan to expose the bearing, then Supaglued the reservoir onto the fan -Silicone Rubber may be better but SupaGlue is quicker & I wanted to keep printing.

The 3mm hole is printed undersize, I just ram a 3mm tap through it, as printing very small threads never works for me.

I sucked some of my Car's Full Synthetic oil into a syringe, squirted it into the reservoir, then put a 3mm screw in to keep out dust & other gunk.

title: Combined Lead Screw Bracket and Bed Mount

description.text:
I found that the motor mounts for the Z-axis couldn't slide out far enough for the lead-screws to line up. Since I'm building the 300x300 version, I wanted to make use of the middle-of-the-bed heatbed mounting points along the side, too, so I couldn't just flip the Z-axis bed supports from the inside to the outside of the O & P rails. Options some people have used were cutting a notch out of either the 2x1 plate or the motor mount itself, but I didn't want to degrade the strength of the parts.

So, here's a combined bed mount and motor mount that you can use in place of a middle bed mount, if you're looking for that sort of thing.

All measurements for the bed support are the same:
34mm hole, 34 mm from the edge, 118 mm deep for the screw
30mm x 60mm x 90mm rectangular hole for the nut

The lead screw mount is identical, save that it's 3/16 thicker. The counter-sunk screw holes are the same distance from the rail as before, so you can use the same screws.

author: jonelvis74

description.text:
Lm6uu dimensions but for 1/4" rod: I designed this bushing as a stand-in to cheaply prototype a design that will eventually use lm6uu bearings and 6mm linear shaft. 1/4" hardware store rod is terrible for linear motion, but it is super cheap and I can grab it 2 blocks away, so this is to knock up designs cheaply and then be replaced with proper parts for the final product. I also included a 6mm version just for kicks.

The print in the photo was done in super-fast-tall-layer-junky mode, which is why it looks so ratty, but it still works fine.

I designed the cutaways to give it a bit of flex to forgive alignment issues. These should print a bit tight you can either run them up and down a shaft until they wear in (or heat up a piece of scrap rod a bit and press the bearing onto it). Polish the cheap rod as best you can, then spray the rod down with silicone lube and work the bearing up and down a bit more until it moves freely.
This snaps in to replace the AshTray on a piper Aerostar.

title: Webcam Camera Platform for T-slot printer frame

description.text:
Set your laptop webcam on a platform for your T-slot framed 3D printer. This is more for a camera with a L shaped bracket that would normally hang over the screen of your laptop. Using T-slot, you can easily swivel the camera view.

The pictures are of the platform, the camera on the platform and the view from the camera as seen on the Octoprint Control page.

I use Octoprint to move the z-axis when necessary. If you tend to manually move your z-axis by twisting each coupling, you'll need to move the platform farther down the frame out of the way.

Camera tip: With this type of camera, the focal length is way off. From the factory, it's setup to capture a foot or two away from the lens.
Since this camera is a few centimeters from what you want to see, you have to open the camera and turn the focus inside.
I had to disassemble the camera, only a couple screws, then twist the camera lens. The lens housing does not freely move, since it has a dab of glue on the threads from the factory. You'll need to break off or cut away the dab of glue to allow the lens housing to twist. It feels like you're breaking something due to the force needed, but it worked out well for me.

If you're not comfortable with opening a camera, get a camera that's designed to change focus.

author: bambiker

description.text:
I wanted a fan to cool the Wanhao Duplicator 6 motherboard that was quieter than the existing 4010 axial fan and provided as good or better cooling without raising the printer or leaving off the bottom cover panel. This is the result. Note that it requires a 6010 or 6015 axial fan as a 25mm fan is way too thick. However, if you want to go that route and are okay with leaving the bottom cover panel off, I've also included an STL for a 5mm M3 spacer so that you can print several and raise the mount to allow clearance for the fan.
You'll need 4 35mm or 40mm long M3 screws to attach it to the motherboard mounts. I purchased mine from Amazon. I'm not including a link because availability changes a lot and it's easier to just search for the style and quantity you want. You'll also want a quiet 6010 fan. I chose this one: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FBPQLKG/. It's plenty good enough for my purposes (~24dB @ 3000RPM @ 12cfm), given that the original fan is lucky to get 9cfm at 34dB. It has sleeve bearings however, so if you find a dual ball bearing fan with specs close to this let me know.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dSxzzTNcqxN

title: Accursed Giant (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When the giant king, Thiazi, stole Idunn and her Apples of Immortality from Asgard, the gods' vengeance was swift. Thor crushed Thiazi's skull with the hammer, Mjolnir, while the giant was halfway through transforming from his guise as a great eagle, sending both of his eyes flying from their sockets. Thiazi now wanders blindly through the mist-haunted city of Helheim, though, as a gift to his daughter, Skadi, and as recompense for killing her father, Odin flung the giant's eyes into the heavens where they shine as twin stars, watching all that happens when the sun falls on the Nine Worlds.

This entry includes an OpenTactics stat card. You can find this and other OpenTactics characters in this expanding collection.

This will be one of several monster pieces available for Swords Against Helheim, an OpenTactics-based (semi-)cooperative dungeon-crawler that's currently on the work bench. More on that soon!

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a single piece box. It's designed for a standard 12v, 80mm computer case fan and 1-2 pieces of flat carbon filter. Filters are cheap and most everyone has an old non-working computer with a fan laying around.
The carbon filter material is the same type you get as a replacement for fume hoods used for solder smoke/fume extraction. You can easily cut the filter material with scissors to fit in the box.

Once printed, slip a layer of carbon filter into the box, then slip in the fan. The fan screws into the back of the box using the same screws you would use with a computer.
The fan holds the filter in place. You may need to squish the fan side of the filter into the box a little if the blades scrape the filter when spinning. I only had to do this on first install. In several months, the filter has not moved back to touch the fan. Depending on your filter thickness, you may have more difficulty with scraping.

With a regular 12V fan, this thing really sucks away the fumes. You can see a line of smoke going straight off the soldering iron into the filter. Just set the fan next to where you're soldering and off goes the smoke.
I printed some feet that clip into the bottom, but that hasn't worked out so well yet. A better way to prop up or hold the box at an angle near the work would be better.

Fidget Spinners are all the rage right now at my son's school. I made a few of the geometric ones, but then I wanted one for myself to be a bit different. I had made this wing for another project (a necklace) a while ago, so I grabbed that model and tweaked it till I got something I liked.

This one uses the standard 608 bearings, and 7/16" - 20 Nuts from the hardware store. They are just press fit (aka) hammered with light taps into place.

TinkerCad is awesome.

The original model was made in Tinkercad. To make the wing I found some Clip art of a wing that had feathers in distinct blocks not connected. I used photo shop to make several images from that original image. One was the complete outline as a solid shape, then the wing outside arch, and the feathers as individual files. I imported each image into Tinkercad, then arranged them all on the main back-outline shape to recreate it. I made each feather section it's own image because I tilted the feathers slightly to give it a little more 3D look to them. Tinkercad is awesome if you use it a lot you can learn cool little tricks.

description.text:
Decided to make an extruder button because I was tired of pushing my thumb down on that annoying allen cap screw whenever I needed to change filament.
Walked through Thingiverse to see what was posted and nothing really struck me as a decent looking button. They were all just fine for their intended purpose and all but I'm somewhat anal retentive and wanted to stay with the general theme I had started so far.

I was in the air about supports as it is fairly small anyway and messed up overhangs wouldn't be too noticeable but went with them anyway. I was pleasantly surprised to find that they came away rather cleanly and the piece came away looking not entirely bad at all. The supports up the center even pulled right out as I lifted it from the bed.
I used a skirt but I don't think that was even necessary. Use what you will.

title: Prusa i3 MK2(S) Raspberry Pi + 3.5" PiTFT+  Frame Mount

description.text:
Inspired by A number of Octopi cases I've seen as well as:

  • AdaFruits 3.5" PiTFT OctoPrint Rig
  • Raspberry 7-inch LCD mount from another site
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146541

I designed/remixed this to meet my needs. It will be added to as I wire/design my final OctoPi Camera enclosure, but for now this is just the frame mount. It began as a simpler frame clip type mount based loosely on the above thingiverse mount, but the dovetail I used (and a poor selection of printing in PLA) resulted it its failure, this mount proved to be much better, the added spacing allowed power/HDMI cables to be connected easier and allowed it to be adjusted in angle.

Additions I haven't yet included:
Zip Tie attachment points
cable routing
Modified Camera Cable & sensor wire passthroughs

Since a few people have asked, I thought I had referenced it earlier, but the specific control UI on the Raspberry Pi shown is:

OctoPi/OctoPrint: http://octoprint.org/download/
with the plugin TouchUI: http://plugins.octoprint.org/plugins/touchui/

Its the single best upgrade/add-on I've found, and even without the tft display (which I didn't add until... about a week after using it in a previous enclosure) makes a world of difference, remotely monitoring/uploading and controlling a print from the PC makes printing so much easier.

Included is the Sketchup file I'm working in scaled to meters, export STL's in meters and it should shrink appropriately.

Updated to add a V2 of the case, this is for people that need more room for electronics/GPIO hookups, it splits the case into 3 parts, adding a removable back which can be cut/adjusted as need be without reprinting the whole support assembly.

title: Light evolving lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I forgot the little red gear for the stepper motor! its included now :-)

Light evolving lamp

This is an experimental lamp. The idea is that you can put different objects on top of it to create different shadow/light reflections on the wall :-)

It’s a rotating platform made of semitransparent PET-G.
Inside are 2 LEDstrips I got out of 2 cheap “usb led lamps”. See picture.

It’s all about the shadows and reflex ions on the wall behind it.
By putting different shaped objects on top of it, you get different reflections en shadows.
The platform can also rotate and has three holes in the top. This makes the reflections move and transform. The rotating can be controlled with an Arduino Nano and a 28BYJ-48 stepper.
The two bearings are standard 22mm diameter x 7mm with an 8mm hole.
Between these bearings I placed a spacer. See picture. The bearings had been in the fridge before mounting them.

It’s hard to catch these effects by camera, so the photos don’t do it any justice.
I also made a sort video, so you can see it a bit better (video is speeded up :-) ).

I also included a very simple Arduino script and the StepperMotor.h library.
This is the script I tested this with, but it’s not very efficient. It is very easy to use for people who do not have experience with Arduino, though :-). The idea is to experiment with different moves.
Very important is to kill power to this motor after every move, otherwise your motor will get so hot that the plastic melts! (it's also in the Arduino Script)
PS: 2400 steps is one rotation for this mini stepper.

The Arduino and stepper are powered by a 9 V adapter and the 2 LEDstrips with an old 5 V adapter, but you can let it all run on one 5V adapter if you like.
Off course you can put any light source in, if it fits.

title: Daily Equation #10 - Sinc Function - y = a*sin(b*x)/(b*x)

description.text:
This is Day 10 of my collection of printable equations. To see the whole collection, go to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227210 Based on gregsmith_to's request in the comments, (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227223/#comments), for today's equation, I'm doing the Sinc function, y = asin(bx)/(b*x), which is used in signal processing (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinc_function). I've uploaded two different versions of the equation, with different ranges. Per another request, I've included the Openscad file in case someone wants to modify the text or stand. Details:
  • There's a surprise guest in the pictures.
  • units are in mm
  • a = 5000
  • b = 1080/200 (1st), and 720/100 (2nd)
  • Range(x) = 0.001 to 200 (1st), and 0.001 to 100 (2nd)
  • I'm still using the original algorithm for creating the thick curve, which can produce artifacts at rapid changes in slope. I'm working on an improved algorithm that will filter out the artifacts, but haven't had time to finish it.
    • As always, I'm going to continue to post one equation per day until get bored or people lose interest. If there's a particular equation you'd like to see, leave a comment and I'll give it a shot.
All files can be printed without support. Photos shown were printed on a Replicator 2 and sliced using the standard setting on Makerware.

title: C3PO Head Split - Suit "still to come"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I have 2 & half incomplete full size R2D2's and of course you can't have them with out R2's favorite side kick C3PO. Started the head thus far and will up load more files of the body as time permits, Cheers Jace

1/06/2017 Just started to print the front of the Helmet tonight. No support : ) Will see how it goes and post some picks soon. I've added the Parts file 1-2-3 early but could be premature of me. The files look good and should print well, so I'm confident. My printers might print other wise ; ) fingers crossed. Well parts 1,2 & 3 all printed perfecty without the need for support. Each file used 100gms of plastic so lite too

2/06/2017 Just going to print 4, 5 & 6 and will see how they turn out tomorrow. Files uploaded now for any one interested ; ) Cheers Jace
3/06/2017 4,5 & 6 printed fine but it was difficult to remove the support from the eyes so I did a second set of eyes Pt4a that worked great

4/06/2017 Ok head is complete and all the files worked like a dream, which is always a good start ; ) Starting to split up the chest now : ) Will be a big job to ensure the most optimised print. Will up load more files soon

10/06/2017 I've been trying to find references to sizing as I suspect the head is slightly to big. Any one printing this may want to reduce the head files 5 - 10% Cheers Jace

21/06/2017 Just added the back of the head, thought I had already. Thanks to Psylockybee for pointing that out, Someones paying attention ; ) Cheers Jace

author: Jace1969

description.text:
My wife likes Victorian things, and we found these awesome faux-Victorian iron shelf brackets in a shop a while back. I needed to make some small shelves for the same area of the living room so I decided to make some smaller brackets in the same style. I found a similar shape online (using the google search "wrought iron shelf brackets victorian"), and used Photoshop/Inkscape to turn the decorative scroll work into a vector file I could import into Tinkercad. Then just added the brackets, and screw holes and done.

The intent is to mount them with screw holes to the inside, so I added a slight V groove to the edge to make it look slightly inset. This puts the matte bottom surface facing out, which I think works.

The board I will be using will 4" pine board (which comes out to less than 4 so I made these around 3 1/2".

EDITED
I modified the the ends of brackets to make them slightly shorter and rounded them a little. These fit the boards a little better and look nicer. These are marked v3.

Printing note: The brackets are symmetrical so you really don't need to print both L and R brackets.

author: lengay

description.text:
A simple camera cover for Surface Pro 4 laptop-tablet hybrid devices.

Much of the plastic you may be printing with will be partly transparent at the thickness of the rendered STL for this part. However, it should be enough to make almost any details unrecognizable. You are advised to test with the cameras in your device. You can also adjust the wall thickness in the Open SCAD sources, and re-render.

There is a microphone hole in the rendered STL. You could remove it, and re-render. However, be advised that this type of cover does almost nothing to prevent the microphone from picking up sound waves around your device.

The no-cameras symbol used on the front is from https://openclipart.org/download/189154/no-camera-sign.svg where it has been distributed in the Public Domain. Open SCAD has trouble rendering a union between this extruded sign and the rest of the part, so there is a Meshmixer file with the two that you can use to render an STL.

Please, use the Open SCAD source to customize the initial part for your needs.

author: jacob-danell

description.text:
Magnetic fidget spinner using magnets to show the speed of the spinner. As the rotational speed increases, the magnets move further from the center bearing which can be used to gauge the speed.

Use the following:
1 - ceramic 608 bearing*: the bearing needs to be non-magnetic otherwise the magnets will stick to the bearing and add a lot of drag.
4 - 10mm x 8mm cylinder magnets*: other lengths may work too. Be careful with these, they're quite strong and somewhat brittle.
4 - 6mm x 3mm cylinder magnets*: these go into the ends of the spinner and need to be installed to oppose the larger magnets.

Printed in Filamentum Vertigo Gray* (donated by Prusa Research).

*affiliate links

comments.text: Whats keeps the magnets equally spaced during spinning? As in one side moving slightly more then the other causing an off balance further throwing the weights more out of alliance? (chrome suggested alliance instead of balance.... it almost fits lol)
comments.author: MNicky008

comments.text: I do really like the idea though.
comments.author: MNicky008

comments.text: It looks like it would require a specific type of bearing, otherwise the magnets would probably halt the spin entirely. I think I'm going to hold off on printing this one, I like the idea too though, would love to see a video of the concept in action
comments.author: MNicky008

comments.text: I'm wondering if it would help to add a drop of glue to them, I might try that if I end up printing this. Otherwise, maybe they would just stick because they're magnets :D
comments.author: MNicky008

comments.text: The large magnets are pushed in mostly by the repelling force from the smaller magnets in the edges, not so much by the large magnets attraction to each other.  So the distance between the large magnets and the smaller edge magnets depends of the centripetal vs magnetic forces, which should be the same on either side.
comments.author: MNicky008

comments.text: How are the magnets placed? do you insert them part way through the print?
comments.author: C9Des

comments.text: No, you can slide them in from the central hole before you put in the bearing.  The bearing is clamped by the two sides and should stay in place on its own, but you can use some glue or tape to make it more secure.
comments.author: C9Des

title: CD Prayer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The compact disk used to be a symbol of the multimedia era, but it became the latest out-of-date media. In Singapore, it is quite hard to buy a new CD even though there are some shops that still sell vinyl records. Most people listen music via the Internet, not physical media.

CD Prayer is a Buddha statue praying for media that we once loved. CD Prayer revives a CD as a halo of Buddha and plays hi-fi music.

http://katsumotoy.com/
After printing the model, I combined it with Philips Portable CD Player (EXP2546).

title: 120 mm fan to 125 mm / 5" tube adapter (125 mm outer diameter), Cigarette/Nicotine-Filter

description.text:
Thx to Neon22 for his great customizable thing! The original thing and customizer can be found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015874

This a 120 mm fan to 125 mm duct adapter.
The fan is connected to an activated carbon air filter (industrial version, check out Ebay and growshops). The guy who lived here before us was a smoker so we use this filter to clean the air from cigarette smell. I use this kind of filters for more than 8 years now and they work perfectly in our bedroom and living room, way better than the very noisy Honeywell we tried before.

The old 230 V fan was connected to 80 V and it was almost noiseless but 25 W per hour was way too much for 24/7/365 (219 kW per year, ~65 €).

The new fan is sufficient (Papst 4412 FGM 12 [email protected] V, <1 W). It is running for several months now.

Edit:
It is a hot summer and I am also using this thing at my desk with a 12V [email protected] connected to USB. It works perfectly! Don't forget to add a (printed) protective grill. I use these two parts to connect my 12V fan to a power bank (5V):
https://www.banggood.com/USB-Port-to-5_5mm-2_1mm-5V-DC-Barrel-Jack-Power-Cable-Connector-p-997025.html?p=X314171248723201502R

https://www.banggood.com/5_52_1mm-DC-Power-Male-Female-Plug-Jack-Adapter-Connector-for-CCTV-LED-5050-3528-5630-Strip-Light-p-1111850.html?p=X314171248723201502R

35° extension for this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2353607
More 125 mm ducts: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2354806

Dimensions:
Height: 55 mm
OD: 125 mm
ID: 122 mm
Wall thickness: 1.5 mm

Hint:
If you plan to use it with an activated carbon air filter check the dimensions of your filter before printing.

author: TDO

description.text:
This is a test thing
This model was made in Morphi! http://www.morphiapp.com. In Morphi, people of all skill levels can make 3D printable models on the go using touch, without wifi or a mouse. Download the app for free in the App store. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android.

This model was made in Morphi! http://www.morphiapp.com. In Morphi, people of all skill levels can make 3D printable models on the go using touch, without wifi or a mouse. Download the app for free in the App store. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android.

It battery adapter can let you use Li-ion battery(10440) to replace old 4V lead acid battery

You also need order material as below:
Copper foil
Conductive gasket

You can use 2 of 10440 battery (3.7~4.2v in parallel)

This is a hook knife that you print in two parts. I used ABS for testing and it holds itself together firmly with friction, for exchanging blades, though acetone could make a more permanent seal between sides. It's designed to be small enough to avoid cutting fingers. The finger hole is designed to fit 3 fingers with thin or no gloves and 2 fingers with winter gloves. I found it comfortable holding it a couple different way and the simplicity makes it easy in emergency situations. Simply place two DE razors on the 3 studs and press the two halves together. I am open to suggestions because I want to fulfill certain nitch needs. This design was inspired by Byron Leisek's paramotor crash (https://youtu.be/W-1RW0HsXSE?t=5m44s). After a midair encounter with another pilot, he threw his reserve but his glider reflated and dove nose first pulling him faster towards the ground. He didn't have time to pull in his glider but had this hook knife been hanging from his carabiner, where his hands naturally were, he'd have had enough time to cut at least one riser's worth of lines. Coincidentally, he was also wearing bulky winter gloves when it happened. I want to apply my skills to these types niche issues that we run into while the sport is young, so that someday my children can experience safer flight. So if it's helpful to you, follow! Everything posted goes through real life testing. I will only post iterations of safe and working knives.

Printing
All testing is done as the stl is with no supports .2mm abs
with the exception of the attachments.
I suggest printing the hook knife in red and the case in the color of your choice.
with 30% infill it comes out at 2.48 ounces.

You need

  • 2 Standard DE razors
  • Glue or ABS/Acetone (optional)

v2 update

  • 2mm thinner, making it easier to cut through fabric straps and seatbelts.
  • reinforced thin area between blades, and moved it back making it easier to cut multiple lines at once (paragliding)
  • adjusted angle of thumb
  • added tether hole for attaching paracord.
  • added 7th peg near bottom to further secure the two parts together
  • removed fillet for strength and grip with thinner version

v2 Case

  • The case is a yank away design with all attachments. A thumb lever makes it easy to load but in the event of an emergency, grab the handle and yank.
  • v2 Case is designed to allow attachments that are friction pressed into place. Glue can be applied here for a more permanent solution.
  • v2 Case velcro is just a flat back for glueing on velcro.
  • there are two types of clips, the normal clip is meant to be removable for clipping to belt
  • clipalt is an alternate design where once bolted down, it is not designed to come off easily. It'd be difficult to clip on and off of belt but would make a permanent safety feature to a paramotor/paraglider harness. (different sizes upon request)
  • Squeezed just a bit more room out of the fingers hole.
  • Added important notch that allows the hook knife to securely clip into case. Consider this the first working case. (5/30/2017)
  • Now hardware free! Everything is friction fit and removable!

Any business looking to distribute these, please contact me.

Printed in ABS or PETG, the plastic will easily hold up to any weather conditions you throw at it. title: Anet A6 Front Frame Y-Axis Reinforced

description.text:
Remixed. Added Brace structure to prevent bending and punched holes to reduced amount of material required. A LOT stiffer than fragile and brittle Anet original front Y axis frame.
Because the original design was made to print flat on the bed, it warps easily due to uneven cooling of outer edges. Also warps when printed upright.
This vertical print layout features two little feet to enable 2 mm of support, which will allow cooling of initial layers.
After wasting so much filament on warped prints, this gave best results for highest print reliability.Just make sure Z-axis has braces to reduce wobble.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Must have 195 mm Z-axis print capacity. Designed to print vertically to reduce warping. Print with Max Cooling fan and minimum Extruder heat to prevent warping due to uneven cooling.
Supports are required and are designed to help with cooling of initial layers.
Raft is required for best adhesion due to minimal foot print.
DO NOT SLOW DOWN print speed in attempt to reduce warping. It will cause clogging and stringing. Print with 100% of normal print speed for printer.

A sturdy one piece propeller guard for the Kingkong 90GT. I have printed it in ABS. It weighs 15 grams.

Fits any spindle with standard 43 mm neck like Kress and similar.

After reviewing spindle mount on Thingiverse I decided to model a stronger one according to aluminium models sold on eBay.

This one is 15 mm high with 4 M5 mount holes 20x80 mm apart to mount on e.g. 20-series extrusion.
You can modify the mount as you like by editing the openSCAD file.

Assembly

Use a M6x50 hex socket cap screw and a M6 flat head insert nut. Heat the nut (by gas or soldering iron) and insert into plastic.
